summary_variants.short_answer: Nelson Mandela was a South African anti-apartheid leader who became the country's first democratically elected president in 1994.
summary_variants.kid_friendly: Nelson Mandela worked for fairness in South Africa. After many years in prison, he helped bring peace and became president.
summary_variants.standard: Nelson Mandela (1918–2013) was a South African lawyer, anti-apartheid organizer, and the first Black president of South Africa. After serving 27 years in prison for his activism, he negotiated the end of apartheid and led a government focused on reconciliation and institution building from 1994 to 1999.
summary_variants.expert_notes: Mention the Rivonia Trial, Robben Island imprisonment, negotiations with F.W. de Klerk, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, and long-term regional diplomacy.

roles_offices: President of the African National Congress (1991–1997)
notable_actions: Led the African National Congress's armed wing Umkhonto we Sizwe
Negotiated the end of apartheid with the National Party government
Helped establish the Truth and Reconciliation Commission
